ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: DARPA Grand Challenge
ygData.msgSnippet: ... That sounds like fun, consider me made envious :) ... Ok so I guess you move in curves a lot because you are constantly having to adjust direction to avoid

Mitchell Timin wrote:

>--- Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
>
>By 'high-level' task I meant a NN that would receive
>at it's inputs 
>the bearing and distance of a target location plus
>information about 
>local obstacles. The output of the NN would then be
>a bearing and 
>speed the vehicle should go in in order to get to
>the target 
>location, but avoiding the local obstacles. A model
>can be built for 
>this task and an NN evolved for it.
>
>  
>
>
>I don't think that for desert racing the task is
>separable in the way you propose, although it would
>depend on the characteristics of the particular
>terrain.  Would you believe I have personal experience
>racing a motorcycle on the desert? :)  It's true; it
>was in California in 1961.  I used to be a dirt-biker.
>  
>
That sounds like fun, consider me made envious :)

>But my assertion is that the vehicle spends at least
>50% of its time moving in a curved path.  Hence it is
>more appropriate that the ANN output steering and
>throttle information.  These outputs will rarely be
>constant, but rather continually changing.
>
Ok so I guess you move in curves a lot because you are constantly having 
to adjust direction to avoid oncoming onbstacles. For very large 
obstacles you will tend to follow a path of shortest distance around the 
obstacle, which is more likely to be a series of straight lines. I still 
think my layered models could work here because each of them would 
constantly be receiving fresh input. So if for instance there was a 
large circular crater we had to get around and we were due south of it 
and the target position is to the north. The local-navigation NN would 
see that it cannot go due north and would pick the best trajectory 
possible, east or west. As we make our way around the crater it is 
constantly adjusting the heading (towards north) so that we follow the 
edge of the crater - thus following a curved path.

Thinking about your comments I do now see a greater problem though. In 
complex terrains there is a very likely possibility that you could get 
stuck in a dead-end of sorts. To solve this problem you either need a 
rough predetermined route or perhaps some kind of maze searching 
technique, so e.g. if you find yourself in a dead-end you backtrack, and 
try another route from some previously traversed point. This isn't an 
area I have knowledge of but I would imagine that this could be a tricky 
problem for ANNs to solve alone. Us humans have the advantage in this 
area of being able to make out large obstacles such as valleys, or 
canyon walls. We can therefore make good assumptions about where 
dead-ends are likely to be and work out good possible routes in our 
heads before we even start the engine!

I still think that the task as a whole can be split of into different 
layers. Some of those layers will be traditional software, some will be 
NN that can be evolved in the lab with simulations and some I see now 
will be a real pain with no immediately obvious or easy solution!

Colin.
